author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Measles Cases Bring Temporary Halt to Afghans’ Arrival in U.S.
description: The C.D.C. asked that the evacuation flights from overseas bases be suspended after four Afghans were found to be infected.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration halted flights carrying Afghan evacuees to the United States from military bases overseas after discovering a few of the new arrivals had measles, the latest hurdle in a haphazard effort to assist allies hoping to flee the Taliban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What the recall means for the future of mail-in voting.
description: The number of ballots cast before the election hints at a significant shift in California.
content: More than a third of California’s active registered voters had cast their ballots in the recall election by Saturday, several days before polls close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Chiarito
title: In Chicago, people climb steps to remember emergency workers lost on 9/11.
description: More than 500 people, many of them firefighters in full uniforms, climbed 2,200 steps at Chicago’s Soldier Field on Saturday to remember the victims of Sept. 11.
content: More than 500 people, many of them firefighters in full uniforms, climbed 2,200 steps at Chicago’s Soldier Field on Saturday to remember the victims of Sept. 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Going Back Twenty Years to Look Forward
description: A special section doesn’t describe the events of Sept. 11, 2001, as much as it explores what happened after the attacks.
content: In The New York Times’s 18-page section dedicated to the 20th anniversary of Sept. 11 in Sunday’s paper, there is surprisingly little accounting of the events of the day itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: Violent extremists at home and abroad ‘are children of the same foul spirit,’ George W. Bush says in Pennsylvania.
description: Former President George W. Bush commemorated the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on Saturday by speaking at the Flight 93 National Memorial near Shanksville, Pa.
content: Former President George W. Bush commemorated the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on Saturday at the Flight 93 National Memorial in Pennsylvania, recalling a time of American unity and drawing a sharp contrast with the present-day divisiveness of the country’s politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: The winner will take home $2.5 million.
description: Prize money for the runner-up is $1.25 million.
content: It’s not about money for the unlikely U.S. Open finalists Leylah Fernandez and Emma Raducanu. But the money certainly won’t hurt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Trump May Be Gone, But the Fight Against His Border Wall Goes On
description: Residents in Los Ebanos, Texas, on the Rio Grande thought Joe Biden’s victory would end their fears of losing their property for a wall. It hasn’t worked out that way.
content: LOS EBANOS, Texas — The men showed up unannounced, but it didn’t take long for Aleida Flores Garcia to figure out why they were measuring portions of her backyard. “We are here to mark where a border wall would go,” they told her last summer as they surveyed the ranch her family has owned for five generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: At Army Football Game, Sept. 11 Anniversary Lends Tone of Solemnity
description: The context of the moment — with respect to 20 years ago and recent events in Afghanistan — was not lost on players, alumni and recruits.
content: WEST POINT, N.Y. — At 8:46 on Saturday morning, the unmistakable aroma of grilled sausages and just-cracked-open beer wafted through parking lot E above Michie Stadium, the quaint football field nestled on the banks of the Hudson River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Schoch
title: Parents of Young Children Desperately Seek Vaccine Trials
description: Schools have reopened around the country, and families with those under 12 are finding ways to get their kids inoculated, even though they’re not officially eligible yet.
content: Leng Vong Reiff had just received her second dose of a Covid vaccine and thought guiltily of her two young, unvaccinated sons. So she began banging away at her keyboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Téa Kvetenadze
title: Windows on the World employees are remembered amid calls for better pay for service workers.
description: Hillary Clinton, Kirsten Gillibrand and Chuck Schumer commemorated the service workers who died at the World Trade Center.
content: Survivors, labor leaders and politicians came together on Saturday afternoon to commemorate the 73 employees of a World Trade Center restaurant who died on 9/11, and to call for improved conditions in the service industry nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Kristian Thacker
title: In Shanksville, Preserving the Memory of 9/11 and the Wars That Followed
description: After Flight 93 went down, once unthinkable duties were thrust upon the community, including young people who found themselves coming of age in a time of war.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Quandary at U.N.: Who Speaks for Myanmar and Afghanistan?
description: Governments of the two countries have been toppled by pariah regimes. Will they get seats at the world’s biggest diplomatic table anyway?
content: Myanmar’s brutal military coup and the Taliban’s triumphal return to power in Afghanistan are among the crises confronting the United Nations as it convenes its annual General Assembly this coming week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: 20 Years On, the War on Terror Grinds Along, With No End in Sight
description: The failures in Iraq and Afghanistan obscure what experts say is the striking success of a multilateral effort that extends to as many as 85 countries.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: At Selfridges, Weddings Are on the Fourth Floor
description: Department stores are broadening their offerings to survive online sales. A London landmark will host your wedding.
content: LONDON — When Carlene Noel and Danny Sains exchanged vows on Saturday they weren’t just merging their two families into one, they were also marking an unusual expansion of the offerings of a British department store. The new Mr. and Ms. Sains got married on the fourth floor of the stately flagship of Selfridges, on London’s Oxford Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Teen Participant in ‘Slender Man’ Stabbing to Be Released From Mental Hospital
description: Anissa Weier, 19, requested her release in a letter this March. “If I am to become a productive member of society, I need to be a part of society,” she wrote.
content: A 19-year-old woman who participated in the nearly fatal stabbing of a friend, a crime she said was carried out to gain the favor of a sinister fictional character called Slender Man, will be released from a psychiatric hospital on Monday, a Wisconsin judge ruled on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: For a Fractured Israel, a Film Offers Ominous Lessons From Ancient Past
description: An animated epic depicting a Jewish civil war and the destruction of the Second Temple 2,000 years ago is being seen as a warning in a deeply divided country.
content: JERUSALEM — A gripping political thriller swept across cinema screens in Israel this summer, with the movie prompting impassioned debate and striking a particularly resonant chord with Israel’s precarious new government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Manning Up, Letting Us Down
description: Overdosing on macho after 9/11 led America astray.
content: WASHINGTON — I’m not one of those people who think women make naturally better leaders than men, more collegial and collaborative. I’ve covered enough women in the upper ranks, and worked for and with enough women, to know that it depends on the individual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Raducanu wins a stirring first set, 6-4.
description: The 18-year-old from Britain was one set away from becoming the first qualifier to win a grand slam singles title.
content: Continuing a streak that began in the qualifying draw, Emma Raducanu won her 19th consecutive set at this U.S. Open in style, but it was a battle like none have been before for her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Nickolas Davatzes, Force Behind A&E and the History Channel, Dies at 79
description: He led the cable giant, whose eclectic mix of shows would include collaborations with the BBC and documentary-style series like “Hoarders.”
content: Nickolas Davatzes, who was instrumental in creating the cable television networks A&E and the History Channel, which now reach into 335 million households around the world, died on Aug. 21 at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: What Can Sports Teach Us?
description: Sports matter, even if you don’t identify as a fan.
content: Good morning, and welcome to the first issue of my newsletter (you are reading the web version), a place where I hope to discuss the obsessions, ideas and thought processes that have shaped and guided my career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Biden Doubled Mask Fines. What Does It Mean for Air Passengers?
description: Battles over mask-wearing in airports and on planes have become common, but how many people actually end up getting fined? And who’s in charge of the process?
content: On Thursday, in a wide-ranging speech outlining aggressive steps to curb the spread of the coronavirus, President Biden announced that the Transportation Security Administration would double fines for travelers who refuse to wear masks in airports and on commercial airplanes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon are sturdy features in the landscape.
content: ACROSTIC — Once again, Team Cox-Rathvon presents a passage that speaks to me personally: I have a scar on my right leg from one of the evil, evil plants that we read about today, and the author of the passage doesn’t sound too fond of them, either. That author is Mary Hunter Austin, a naturalist who wandered alone through the Southwest in the 19th century, encountering all manner of desert fauna and flora (in heavy skirts, and hopefully unscathed). The passage comes from a book called “The Land of Little Rain,” published in 1903; Austin meets with adversity but also expresses admiration for yuccas, coyotes, cactuses and everything that scratches out a life in such harsh environs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin, Alexandra E. Petri, Katie Rogers and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: The C.D.C. reports that unvaccinated Americans are 11 times more likely to die if infected: The week in Covid news.
description: Unvaccinated Americans were 4.5 times more likely than vaccinated individuals to become infected with the coronavirus, and they were 10 times more likely to be hospitalized and 11 times more likely to die from it, according to one among a handful of studies highlighting the effectiveness of the shots.
content: Unvaccinated Americans were 4.5 times more likely than vaccinated individuals to become infected with the coronavirus, and they were 10 times more likely to be hospitalized and 11 times more likely to die from it, according to one among a handful of studies highlighting the effectiveness of the shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: His Basketball Camp Made Hall of Famers. Now He’s One, Too.
description: Howard Garfinkel co-founded the Five Star Basketball Camp, which trained big-name stars like Michael Jordan, Patrick Ewing and Grant Hill.
content: Grant Hill was introduced to the Five Star Basketball Camp in the form of a Sports Illustrated article that was published in 1984, when he was 11 years old. As Hill flipped through the pages of the magazine, he found himself transfixed. To him, Five Star sounded like basketball nirvana, an exclusive destination where promising players could consume the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Victor J. Blue
title: At Pro-Taliban Protest, a Symbol of America’s Lost Influence: Faces Obscured by Veils
description: Several hundred women wore the head-to-toe garments at a pro-Taliban demonstration on Sept. 11. The march was a reminder of how after years of war, Afghanistan’s women are again at the mercy of the militants.
content: Hundreds of women, many wearing full-length robes, their faces obscured by black veils, filled the auditorium of a Kabul university on Saturday holding signs — many of them in English — in support of the Taliban and its strict interpretation of Islam, including separate education for men and women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas, Robert Gebeloff and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: Phony Diagnoses Hide High Rates of Drugging at Nursing Homes
description: At least 21 percent of nursing home residents are on antipsychotic drugs, a Times investigation found.
content: The handwritten doctor’s order was just eight words long, but it solved a problem for Dundee Manor, a nursing home in rural South Carolina struggling to handle a new resident with severe dementia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Benjamin Novak
title: Meeting Hungary’s Strongman, Pope Treads a Fine Line With an Embattled Leader
description: Pope Francis’ meeting with Viktor Orban could help, or hurt, the prime minister’s efforts to curry favor with voters ahead of coming elections in Hungary, which is predominantly Catholic.
content: BUDAPEST — Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary portrays himself as the defender of Christian Europe against migrants and multiculturalism. After years of his weakening of democratic institutions, the far-right strongman has prepared for coming elections in Catholic-majority Hungary by strengthening his links to Catholic traditionalists in Europe and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Venus Williams
title: Venus Williams: The Thing That Has Really Made Me Tough
description: I used to think that winning depended on my physical health. Then my mother taught me that that was only the half of it.
content: I’m sitting at my desk after having to pull out of this year’s U.S. Open with a leg injury. Managing physical ailments is always difficult, but it’s part of a professional athlete’s job. I have always understood this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Katie Rogers
title: At 9/11 Ceremonies, Moments of Silence, Tributes and Tears
description: Twenty years after the worst attack on American soil, the loss of nearly 3,000 people was remembered in events across the country.
content: The loved ones gathered again in Lower Manhattan for moments of silence and the peals of the bells. They paid tribute to those they lost 20 years earlier and listened as Bruce Springsteen sang about memory and loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Markham
title: The Unnecessary Cruelty of America’s Immigration System
description: We can protect human rights, lower  costs and ensure that people show up to immigration proceedings, without detaining thousands.
content: One day in the spring of 2019, a young Honduran man in a detention center in Ferriday, La., began to feel strange. He’d recently heard from his lawyers that his request to be released on humanitarian parole while his asylum case was pending had been denied. As he swayed on his feet, his skin breaking out into hives, he suspected that the stress of facing more time in a prison cell had brought on a panic attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Kellen Browning
title: A Nick to Apple’s Profits Could Be a Windfall for App Developers
description: After a judge opened up a way to avoid Apple’s commission on their sales, companies big and small are seeing dollar signs.
content: Apple has taken to calling its iPhone App Store an “economic miracle,” and it has pointed to developers like Zach Shakked as proof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Richard Fausset and J. David Goodman
title: Biden’s Sweeping Vaccine Mandates Infuriate Republican Governors
description: Some employers and business groups welcomed the new coronavirus requirements, but many G.O.P. leaders issued outright condemnations.
content: President Biden’s orders pushing millions of workers to get vaccinated were aimed at turning the tide on a pandemic that has killed 650,000 Americans. But on Friday, the mandates immediately deepened the nation’s political divisions over coronavirus vaccinations and government power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Newsom’s Strategy for California Recall: It’s Me or the Abyss
description: Ahead of the vote on Tuesday, the governor is running not so much on his own policies as against the influence of a certain former president.
content: SACRAMENTO — As the campaign to oust him heads into its final weekend, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California is hammering home the choice he has presented to voters since the start of the recall — Donald J. Trump or him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: The pandemic is a key issue in the recall, and that bodes well for Newsom.
description: A new poll found that most likely voters disagreed with the idea that the governor overstepped his authority in his response to the pandemic.
content: Just a few months ago, when it seemed as though the worst of the coronavirus pandemic was behind us, Republican supporters of the recall felt vindicated and optimistic. The fact that so many people were out and about would only embolden the argument that Gov. Gavin Newsom had been too tough in his lockdown orders last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Always Pay the Rent? It May Help Your Mortgage Application.
description: For decades, regular payments to a landlord haven’t counted for much for many tenants trying to get a mortgage. Fannie Mae aims to change that.
content: Later this month, a group of renters in the United States will get a new break when they try to become homeowners: Their history of consistently paying their landlords will count toward qualifying for a mortgage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Unearthed at a British Golf Course: A Log Coffin From the Bronze Age
description: Workers digging in a pond at the Tetney Golf Club discovered a waterlogged coffin containing the remains of a man who archaeologists said was buried about 4,000 years ago.
content: In July 2018, Hugh Willmott was overseeing the excavation of an Anglo-Saxon burial site in northeast England when a regional preservation official told him about a potentially more exciting find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic Reaches U.S. Open Final, One Victory From a Grand Slam
description: Djokovic beat Alexander Zverev, 4-6, 6-2, 6-4, 4-6, 6-2, and has a chance to become the first man since 1969 to win a calendar-year Grand Slam. He will play Daniil Medvedev in the final on Sunday.
content: Twenty-seven down, one to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Photographs of 9/11
description: Photographers reflect on shooting the terrorist attacks of 9/11 and their aftermath.
content: In 2002, The New York Times won the Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Photography for its coverage of the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath. Two decades later, we asked our photographers to return to their work from that time and reflect on the images they created, and what it took to capture them. Their answers have been edited for length and clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: What a Character!
description: Alex Rosen’s puzzle has that look.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — There’s a great deal of personality in this first Sunday grid from Alex Rosen, who has constructed two daily puzzles so far for The Times, on a Tuesday and a Wednesday. Sunday’s fairly leaps off the page, and there’s even a little choreography. Mr. Rosen is a software engineer living in London; according to the puzzle’s print introduction, his focus is helping computer users avoid email-related security mistakes like clicking on a bad link or accidentally sending an email to the wrong person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: How Math Solved the Case of the Volcanic Bombs That Didn’t Explode
description: Scientists have long been puzzled by flying blobs of magma that remained intact, but didn’t have a good way to study them.
content: It would be reasonable to hear the term “volcanic bomb” and presuppose that such an object tends to explode. But a specific type of volcanic bomb rarely lives up to the second half of its name: These objects get blasted into the air, crash into the ground and disappointingly fail to detonate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: In Shanksville, Biden says the future of democracy is on the line.
description: The president honored the passengers and crew members who confronted terrorists on 9/11 and addressed an existential battle underway in America.
content: Shortly after former President George W. Bush spoke at the Flight 93 memorial in Shanksville, Pa., on Saturday, President Biden arrived to observe a wreath-laying ceremony at the place where, 20 years ago, a plane crashed after brave passengers and crew members confronted the terrorists who had hijacked it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Vaccine Resisters Seek Religious Exemptions. But What Counts as Religious?
description: Major denominations are essentially unanimous in their support of the vaccines against Covid-19, but individuals who object are citing their personal faith for support.
content: When Crisann Holmes’s employer announced last month that it would require all employees to be vaccinated against Covid-19 by Nov. 1, she knew she had to find a way out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: ‘Looking Back, I Am Glad We Played’
description: Stuyvesant High, blocks from the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, finished its football season in 2001 under dour circumstances. Was the attempt at normalcy worth it?
content: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Cristiano Ronaldo Is Back and So Is Manchester United
description: A star returns with two goals in a resounding victory, restoring a sense of confidence to a club accustomed to sure things.
content: MANCHESTER, England — And just like that, everything was exactly as it used to be, as if nothing had ever changed, as if he had never been away. Cristiano Ronaldo had scored, again. Manchester United was winning, again. The fans were exulting, again. He was home, at last, and so were they.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cause for Alarm?
description: Sid Sivakumar makes us think for days in his latest Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — The last time we solved a Sid Sivakumar grid in The New York Times, it was a collaboration with Matthew Stock back in May, another challenging fanned-out construction. This kind of geometric pattern, combined with Saturday cluing, means that a solver has four isolated propellers to flail away at; the momentum I built in the southwest quadrant did nothing for me in the northwest, which was by far my weakest spot.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Buffalo Soldiers Get Statue at West Point
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 11, 2021
content: “When I was coming up we had no role models that we could talk to. We didn’t know we had Buffalo Soldiers. If we had known about that it would have made a difference. Now they have a historical, tangible reference point.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Man With Assault Rifle Pleads Guilty to Threatening Pelosi
description: Cleveland Grover Meredith Jr. wrote the day after the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol that he would put “a bullet in her noggin on Live TV.”
content: A Georgia man who had an assault rifle and was headed to Washington for the Jan. 6 pro-Trump rally at the U.S. Capitol pleaded guilty on Friday to sending threatening text messages about House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 11, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 11, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about security trading in 2020 by Federal Reserve officials misstated the timing of stock disclosures by Randal K. Quarles and Jerome H. Powell. Mr. Quarles’s disclosure was made in 2020, for 2019 transactions. His transactions were not made last summer. And Mr. Powell’s disclosures of 41 transactions were for 2019, not 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Hampton
title: Betraying the Victims of the Opioid Crisis
description: The Purdue Pharma bankruptcy case settlement protected the wealthy and ignored those who suffered.
content: On Sept. 26, 2019, the Department of Justice appointed me to serve on the Official Unsecured Creditors Committee in the bankruptcy case against Purdue Pharma, the company that helped fuel the opioid overdose crisis through the misbranding and reckless marketing of the powerful painkiller OxyContin. The committee acted as a mega-plaintiff, with broad powers to subpoena records, take depositions and cross-examine witnesses. For nearly two years, I attended countless negotiations, depositions and chambers meetings. I read thousands of pages of confidential documents revealing the true nature and depth of Purdue’s liability in the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Kinzer
title: Abimael Guzmán, Leader of Guerrilla Group That Terrorized Peru, Dies at 86
description: Mr. Guzmán’s Maoist movement, Shining Path, killed tens of thousands in the 1980s and ’90s. He sought to bring the world to a “higher stage of Marxism.”
content: Abimael Guzmán, the founder and leader of the Shining Path guerrilla movement, which spread terror across much of Peru in the 1980s and ’90s, died on Saturday in Peru. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden and Bush Urge Unity as Nation Remembers Sept. 11
description: Both President Biden and former President George W. Bush acknowledged that what has happened in the years since has only challenged the notion that Americans found strength in coming together.
content: WASHINGTON — As they traveled the country laying wreaths, strolling through crash sites in pastoral meadows and comforting families whose wounds are ripped open anew each year, two living presidents used the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks to urge Americans to come together in an effort to weather deep political and cultural divisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Hochul, in first 9/11 as governor, emphasizes the human cost of the attacks.
description: The governor announced that she had signed bills intended to help provide emergency workers who worked on 9/11 with better access to state benefits.
content: During her first commemoration of the Sept. 11 attacks as governor, Kathy Hochul spent time with the families of victims at the 9/11 Memorial & Museum in Lower Manhattan, attended a Fire Department Mass and paid tribute to the New York National Guard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hikari Hida and Tiffany May
title: To Survive the Pandemic, a Secret Nintendo Cafe Is Secret No Longer
description: Toru Hashimoto’s Tokyo spot is a showcase for items he kept while working for the video game company. It used to be a members-only hideaway, but financial strain has forced him to open up.
content: TOKYO — Toru Hashimoto ran a cafe he hoped almost nobody could find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: All of the names of those lost in the 9/11 attacks were read out loud.
description: Family members did the reading at a ceremony in Lower Manhattan, which took about four hours.
content: The names of the nearly 3,000 lives lost in the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, were read out loud by family members at a ceremony in Lower Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Can I Figure Out What Repairs a Building Might Need in the Future?
description: You can, and should, find out what problems the board knows about before you agree to buy an apartment. But you can’t foresee everything.
content: Q: I’m considering buying a new place, and I want to know how a prospective buyer of a co-op or condo in New York can find out what repairs the building might need in the next four or five years. I’d hate to be hit with a huge assessment for repairs shortly after I move in, and I certainly don’t want to unknowingly move into a building with structural problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: Painful memory for Muslims: Outrage over a proposed Islamic center in Manhattan.
description: The downtown project was scuttled amid anti-Muslim sentiment. The head of the Anti-Defamation League recently apologized for opposing the plan.
content: To the two men who envisioned it, an Egyptian-American real estate developer and an imam long involved in interfaith initiatives, Park51 was a simple but necessary project: a Muslim community center, modeled on the Jewish Community Center on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, with spaces for worship, athletics and cultural programs, open to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: New York Fashion Week: Day 4
description: Tie-dye never dies.
content: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. Every day we’ll spotlight one thing we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Anna Schaverien
title: Remembering 9/11
description: The weeks and months that followed the attacks were a defining time for many, including on Wall Street.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Mountain of Money Fuels Gavin Newsom’s Surge to Recall Finish Line
description: The California governor has taken full advantage of the state’s loose financing rules for recall elections, overpowering Republican challengers for whom the cavalry never arrived.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom’s bid to fend off a recall in California has been bolstered by an infusion of tens of millions of dollars from big donors in recent months that delivered him an enormous financial advantage over his Republican rivals in the race’s final stretch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: As Democrats Push a $3.5 Trillion Bill, a Top Lawmaker Stays Mum on Tax Increases
description: The silence from Representative Richard Neal of Massachussetts has some liberal Democrats worried that he could thwart the scope of their economic ambitions.
content: WASHINGTON — When Republicans sought to pass a giant tax cut along party lines in 2017, Representative Richard E. Neal of Massachusetts, the top Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, led his party’s effort to brand the legislation as a tax break for the rich, helping erode public support for the bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Gilbert Seltzer, Soldier in the World War II ‘Ghost Army,’ Dies at 106
description: He was one of the last survivors of a band of Army con artists who duped German forces with their arsenal of fakery, including inflatable tanks and scripted radio transmissions.
content: Gilbert Seltzer, who served with a secret Army unit in World War II that fooled German forces with inflatable tanks, dummy airplanes, fake radio transmissions and sound effects that mimicked troop movements, died on Aug. 14 at his home in West Orange, N.J. He was 106.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Kamala Harris: 9/11 shows how ‘fear can be used to sow division.’
description: Speaking at a memorial service for the victims of Flight 93, the vice president emphasized the importance of unity and said the nation’s greatest strength was its diversity.
content: At a memorial for the passengers who fought back against terrorists aboard United Airlines Flight 93, Vice President Kamala Harris warned that the tragedy of the Sept. 11 attacks had shown how “fear can be used to sow division,” and stressed that America’s diversity was its greatest asset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Barred From Flying Over Mask Dispute, Lawmaker Asks to Be Excused From Senate
description: Lora Reinbold, a Republican state senator from Alaska, was captured on video in April arguing with employees at Juneau International Airport about mask rules.
content: An Alaska lawmaker has asked to be excused from legislative sessions until next year, saying she has no way to fly to the state capital after she was barred from Alaska Airlines for violating mask policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Emma Raducanu wins the U.S. Open to complete a miraculous run.
description: Raducanu, ranked 150th in the world and barely known two weeks ago, became the first player to win a Grand Slam title after surviving the qualifying tournament.
content: Emma Raducanu, the 18-year-old British phenom, completed a shocking run through the U.S. Open with a straight-sets victory over Leylah Fernandez of Canada on Saturday for a title that will surely go down as one of the great underdog journeys in the history of sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ‘It’s a Godsend’: 9-Cent Taxi Rides in Rural South Korea
description: One county’s plan to help older, carless citizens stuck in remote villages proved wildly popular and has been copied across South Korea, revolutionizing public transportation in the countryside.
content: SEOCHEON, South Korea — On a recent overcast morning, a village on South Korea’s west coast showed no sign of human stirring until five older residents slowly emerged through the fog that shrouded lush, green rice paddies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharif Hassan
title: ‘Everything Changed Overnight’: Afghan Reporters Face an Intolerant Regime
description: The Taliban promised to respect press freedoms, but the new government has already showed signs of repression, and has even physically assaulted Afghan journalists.
content: Beloved shows removed from the airwaves. A television station cutting from a news report a story about a pregnant police officer who was reportedly fatally shot by the Taliban. A radio editor telling his colleagues to edit out anti-Taliban cheers from coverage of demonstrations in the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Teresa Zylis-Gara, Plush-Voiced Polish Soprano, Is Dead at 91
description: She took on a wide range of roles in her long international career, which included a stretch as a stalwart of the Metropolitan Opera in the 1970s.
content: Teresa Zylis-Gara, a Polish soprano who displayed a plush voice, impressive versatility and beguiling stage presence during a three-decade international career that included a stretch at the Metropolitan Opera during her prime in the 1970s, died on Aug. 28 in Lodz, Poland. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Armstrong
title: She survived 9/11 and Covid: ‘You just keep going.’
description: “If Osama bin Laden didn’t kill me, I’m not dying from a virus,” said Wendy Lanski, who spoke at a memorial in Jersey City.
content: Wendy Lanski, 51, monitored the helicopters flying overhead as she stood by the Empty Sky Memorial inside Jersey City’s Liberty State Park on Saturday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Oregon Upsets Ohio State, Keeping Pac-12 in Playoff Mix
description: Playing before a home crowd for the first time since 2019, Ohio State lost in Columbus for the first time in more than four years.
content: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The Saturday afternoon outlook for the Oregon Ducks, the ones who barely mustered a victory over Fresno State last week, was decidedly poor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Tributes to Sept. 11 victims, survivors, and families from around the world
description: As the United States marks the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, memorials have been held around the world, and tributes have been paid by global leaders.
content: As the United States marks the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, memorials have been held around the world, and tributes have been paid by global leaders, in memory of the victims, survivors and families affected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Denmark lifts the last of its coronavirus restrictions.
description: The country’s health minister said, “This can only be done because we have come a long way with the vaccination rollout, have a strong epidemic control, and because the entire Danish population has made an enormous effort to get here.”
content: Denmark has lifted the last of its coronavirus restrictions, effectively declaring that the virus was no longer a “critical threat to society” and allowing the country to get back to a semblance of prepandemic normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: An astronaut marks the 20th anniversary of 9/11 from space.
description: Shane Kimbrough, a NASA astronaut, remembered the monumental day with remarks from the International Space Station.
content: An astronaut paid tribute from space on the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: How 9/11 Changed a 13-Year-Old Girl in Harlem
description: As a middle school student on Sept. 11, 2001, I didn’t realize how much the terror attacks would affect me and my family.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Special Episode: What Does It Mean to ‘Never Forget’?
description: Twenty years after Sept. 11, a look at what we hold on to and what we choose to let go.
content: Two planes hijacked by Al Qaeda pierced the north and south towers of the World Trade Center. A third slammed into the Pentagon in Arlington, Va. A fourth crashed in an open field outside Shanksville, Pa. All in less than 90 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What Comes After the 9/11 Era?
description: The battle to define the next American grand strategy.
content: When I moved to Washington, D.C., in 2002 we all lived in 9/11’s shadow. We waited for bombs in the Metro, for more anthrax envelopes, for a sequel to the previous autumn’s terror. We watched planes headed for Reagan Airport fly low over the Potomac, always half-expecting them to veer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryn Stole
title: Berlin Clubs Return With a Vengeance
description: A discothèque successfully sued the city over its ban on indoor dancing, and clubs have reopened. But if there’s a spike in coronavirus cases, the local government has explored a backup plan.
content: BERLIN — The beats were pumping inside Salon zur wilden Renate long after the sun had risen. Hundreds of euphoric, maskless revelers crammed onto the dance floor, the only social distancing created in temporary pockets by the rhythmic moving of the crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Where’s Trump on 9/11? Not at ground zero.
description: The former president “decided to honor the day with different stops,” his spokeswoman said, including a visit to a Manhattan police precinct.
content: Notably absent from the 9/11 memorial ceremonies on Saturday was former President Donald J. Trump, a native New Yorker who built much of his political brand in the divisive aftermath of the attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: At 9/11 museum, site of today’s memorial, controversies past and present.
description: At the official memorial site, rough spots over a board trustee, a recent documentary, and canceled exhibits.
content: The 9/11 Memorial & Museum in Lower Manhattan, the host of this morning’s ceremony, is no stranger to controversy, whether before its 2014 opening or in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

title: History on the Line at the U.S. Open Finals 🎾
description: There’s an unexpected all-teenage women’s final, and the men’s top seeds meet with a Grand Slam on the line.
content: There’s an unexpected all-teenage women’s final, and the men’s top seeds meet with a Grand Slam on the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: On the Scene: 9/11 at Guantánamo Bay
description: At Guantánamo Bay, the memory of Sept. 11 is never far away. And not just because the men who are accused of plotting the terrorist attacks are held prisoner here.
content: At Guantánamo Bay, the memory of Sept. 11 is never far away. And not just because the men who are accused of plotting the terrorist attacks are held prisoner here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and The New York Times
title: ‘Unity Is Imperative in America,’ Harris Says at 9/11 Ceremony
description: Vice President Kamala Harris highlighted the importance of unity in America during a memorial service near Shanksville, Pa., for the victims of Flight 93 who were killed 20 years ago.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris highlighted the importance of unity in America during a memorial service near Shanksville, Pa., for the victims of Flight 93 who were killed 20 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso and Nailah Morgan
title: America Observes the 20th Anniversary of 9/11
description: Ceremonies were held in remembrance at the sites where nearly 3,000 people were killed in terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.
content: Ceremonies were held in remembrance at the sites where nearly 3,000 people were killed in terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.
source.name: The New York Times
